titleStmt.title: Variants of Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) closed syllable before ī- taCCīC
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) closed syllable before ī- taCCīC.

revisionDesc.change: updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

item.label: a > the pattern is not used in the dialect

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers show consistent raising of short medial a in unstressed closed syllable before ī, in the pattern taCCīC(v).

Young speakers and some middle-aged speakers do not show raising to i of short medial a in unstressed closed syllable before ī, unlike Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers. Here, instead of a - i these speakers generally show a - ə.

Variation between ta- and ti- in form II maṣādir of is common in the Galilee, both in Bedouin and sedentary dialects, where both forms occur “without any evident regional distribution”, being those starting with ti- fairly more common (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:267).
Conditioning - In the environment of gutural and emphatic consonants a remains.

cit.quote: straightening the wings of a car

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Variation between ta- and ti- in form II maṣādir of is common in the Galilee, both in Bedouin and sedentary dialects, where both forms occur “without any evident regional distribution”, being those starting with ti- fairly more common (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:267).
Conditioning: Raising to ə is blocked when in a gutural or emphatic environment, e.g. baṭṭīx (watermelon)
There are some rare exceptions where raising does not occur, such as šaġġīl
The author does not give an example for the verbal noun of the second stem, but he gives the pattern taCCīC.
Johnstone bases his description of Bahraini Arabic on the dialect of Manama, and does not mention any denominational influences.
Johnstone bases his description of Bahraini Arabic on the dialect of Manama, and does not mention any denominational influences.
in the dialect only the pattern tCiCCiC is used, e.g. tʕimmir 'building'
in this dialect only tCuCCoC is used, e.g. tkunnos 'sweeping'; see Borg 1985:106
